awd_titl_txt: Development of Catalytic Metal-Coupled Electron-Transfer (MCET) for Sustainable Chemical and Electrochemical Oxygen Reduction
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Jerome Robinson of Brown University is working on energy storage.  This theme is relevant to the efficient use of "intermittent energy" from wind and solar sources. This project focuses on the storage of energy in the form of peroxides, compounds with oxygen-oxygen bonds. The use of oxygen is attractive since it is one of the most abundant elements in the earth's atmosphere. Current industrial routes to peroxides are energy-intensive.  The project is also addressing small-scale applications relevant to personalized-energy storage. The research team designs metal catalysts to produce peroxides using electro-chemical means.  This project provides hands-on training opportunities in the areas of renewable energy and green chemistry for scientists at the graduate, undergraduate, and high-school levels. Initiatives focusing on broadening representation and increasing retention in historically underrepresented groups in chemistry are being advanced through summer research opportunities and cohort-based mentor and researcher training programs.

Efficient and controlled delivery of electrons and protons are critical to many sustainable energy applications. Despite significant advances and intensive research interest, achieving high selectivity and activity at low overpotentials with earth-abundant catalysts remains a formidable challenge. With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jerome Robinson of Brown University is advancing the fundamental understanding of catalytic metal-coupled electron transfer (MCET) to enable the sustainable and selective reduction of oxygen to peroxide using earth-abundant catalysts. To achieve this goal, this project is focused on developing electrocatalytic MCET processes for the reduction of oxygen to peroxide, identifying and optimizing conditions for turnover of the Lewis-acid activator, and managing potentially competitive pathways such as proton-coupled electron transfer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
With the support of the Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry at NSF, Prof. Jerome R. Robinson and his group at Brown University studied the underlying principles of metal-ion coupled electron transfer (MCET) and how this phenomenon can be exploited in (electro)catalytic oxygen reduction to access unprecedented catalyst activity and selectivity. The selective (electro)chemical reduction of oxygen is a crucial transformation in both biological and industrial settings, where access to highly active and selective catalysts underlie many key renewable energy technologies.

The primary goal of the proposed research was to advance the fundamental understanding of MCET in the selective chemical and electrochemical reduction of O2 to peroxide to develop systems which are catalytic in Lewis-acid activator. The intellectual merit of this work was the development of a molecular-level understanding of metal-ion binding involved in stoichiometric and catalytic oxygen reduction. This led to the first example of cis / trans isomerization of dicopper oxygen species. Isomerization of cis dicopper oxygen species has been hypothesized to occur in the initial stages of oxygen binding in hemocyanin, the key oxygen transporter in arthropods, but molecular examples of such behavior were absent to our study. We have identified the formation of other heterobimetallic cis peroxides as reactive intermediates responsible for the highly peroxide-selective (electro)catalytic reduction of oxygen promoted with earth-abundant Cu catalysts. Furthermore, these studies have led to the isolation of metal peroxides directly from air, where we discovered the first ambiphilic rare-earth peroxide. The unique mechanism of oxygen reduction has led to our discovery of the (electro)catalytic reduction of oxygen by a lanthanide (catalytic in Lewis acid activator), which display reactivity and selectivity patterns distinct from other parts of the periodic table. These advances were made possible through a strong interplay of experiment and theory, including collaborations with scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

The broader impacts of the work were achieved by broadening participation by engaging underrepresented groups in research and public outreach, broad dissemination of this work through peer-reviewed publications and presentations at (inter)national scientific meetings, and developing programs at the regional, national, and international level for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Furthermore, the research outcomes made possible by this award have provided crucial insight into the field’s understanding of how metal-ion binding events involving ‘redox-inactive’ cations impact stoichiometric and catalytic reduction of oxygen in synthetic and enzymatic catalyst sites. Over the course of this award, four graduate and nine undergraduate researchers participated in this project, > 60% identified as women or from historically underrepresented groups. Key programming involving high schools in Rhode Island built partnerships with public school teachers through the ACS Science Coach program, brought three hundred high school students from six public high schools in Rhode Island to participate in interactive science demonstrations and college access through Brown Chemistry’s STEM Day, and the PI served as the coordinator for the Rhode Island chapter of ACS Project SEED. During the pandemic, the PI served as a co-organizer for Angular Momentum, which served as a free, high-visibility platform for researchers to share research in the area of f-element chemistry.


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Jerome Robinson
